'''''Amanita sphaerobulbosa''''', commonly known as the '''Asian abrupt-bulbed Lepidella''', is a species of [[agaric]] fungus in the family [[Amanitaceae]]. First [[species description|described]] by mycologist [[Tsuguo Hongo]] in 1969,<ref name="Hongo 1969"/> it is found in Southern Asia. The species was formerly consider synonymous with the North American lookalike ''[[Amanita abrupta]]'', but that species has narrower [[spore]]s, a persistent [[partial veil]], and lacks the refractive contents found in the [[hypha]]e and inflated cells of ''A. sphaerobulbosa''.<ref name="urlAmanitaceae.org: Amanita sphaerobulbosa"/>

The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] of ''Amanita sphaerobulbosa'' are damaging to the liver; the toxicity is thought to be largely due to a rare [[amino acid]]. Although not considered as toxic as its infamous relatives the [[Amanita phalloides|death cap]] and the [[Amanita virosa|destroying angel]], ''A. sphaerobulbosa'' is blamed for the deaths of two Japanese women in 1978. Poisoning symptoms included the abrupt appearance of violent vomiting, diarrhea and dehydration after a delay of 10–20 hours.

==Habitat and distribution==
The mushroom has been collected in [[Korea]],<ref name="Kim 1994"/> and [[Japan]].<ref name="Zhang 2004"/>

==Toxicity==

Ingestion of ''Amanita sphaerobulbosa'' fruit bodies is [[hepatotoxicity|toxic to the liver]].<ref name="Kawaji 1990"/> Laboratory experiments have shown that mice that ingested ''A. sphaerobulbosa'' mushroom [[extract]]s developed [[cholera]]-like symptoms. A minimum single [[lethal dose]] of mushroom extract (equivalent to 4.5 grams of [[fruiting body]] per kilogram of mouse body weight) caused mice to become prostrate 6 hours after injection; shortly after the mice had diarrhea, then ultimately died between 24 and 48 hours after administration of the extract.<ref name="Yamaura 1982"/> In [[Nagano, Nagano|Nagano, Japan]] in 1978, two women died from [[mushroom poisoning]] suspected to be caused by this species.<ref name="Yamaura 1985"/> The symptoms were characterized by the abrupt appearance of violent vomiting, diarrhea and dehydration after a delay of 10–20 hours. Although not as toxic as the [[Amanita virosa|destroying angel]] (''A. virosa'') or the [[Amanita phalloides|death cap]] (''A. phalloides''), ''A. sphaerobulbosa'' causes changes in liver function similar to these species. Effects include a decrease in [[blood sugar]] levels, depletion of stored carbohydrate reserves (liver [[glycogen]]), and an [[elevated transaminases|increase in transaminases]].<ref name="Tu 1992"/>

==Biochemistry==

Several novel unusual [[amino acid]]s have been isolated from ''Amanita sphaerobulbosa'', including (2''S'',4''Z'')-2-amino-5-chloro-6-hydroxy-4-hexenoic acid; <small>D,L</small>-2-amino-4-pentynoic acid (0.257% [[w/w]]); and <small>L</small>-2-amino-4,5-hexadienoic acid (0.911% w/w). These last two chemicals are suspected to be largely responsible for the toxic effects of the mushroom as they have also been found in ''A. solitaria'' and ''[[Amanita pseudoporphyria|A. pseudoporphyria]]''.<ref name="Yamaura 1985"/> The chemical 2-amino-4-pentynoic acid (also known as [[propargyl]][[glycine]]) [[enzyme inhibitor|inhibits]] enzymes involved in the [[metabolism]] of the amino acids [[methionine]] and [[cystathionine]] in the liver;<ref name="Awata 1984"/> it was also shown to have mild inhibitory effects on [[glycogenolysis]] in rat [[hepatocytes]].<ref name="Kawaji 1992"/>
